Name.BusinessNameLine1: UNITED STATES GOLF ASSOCIATION FOUNDATION INC

IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: The United States Golf Association Foundation ("USGA Foundation") exists to support the United States Golf Association ("USGA") in its mission to promote and conserve golf's tradition. Both the USGA and the USGA Foundation sponsor a variety of programs that benefit everyone who plays the game.
IRS990.MissionDescription: The USGA Foundation's sole motivation is acting in the best interests of the game of golf for the continued enjoyment of those who love and play it. It does so by supporting the activities of the United States Golf Association, including management of the USGA museum and the USGA archives.
IRS990.Description: USGA Museum & Archives - The museum is an educational institution dedicated to fostering an appreciation for the game of golf and its participants. The USGA and the USGA Foundation serve as caretakers and stewards for the game's history, supporting the USGA's role in ensuring the game's future. By collecting, preserving, and interpreting the historical developments of the game in the United States, with an emphasis on the USGA and its championships, the museum promotes a greater understanding of golf's cultural significance for a worldwide audience. The museum sponsors a rich array of programs designed to educate and inspire the public about the history of golf and the USGA's role in the game's development. The museum offers a wide variety of programming to suit audiences of all ages. Programs and events travel across the country to USGA championship sites, member clubs, regional meetings, and national and local museums and libraries. Also, a comprehensive website allows photos, films and other information to be shared with a wide audience.

Activity2.Description: In accordance with a permanently restricted endowment fund to finance junior golf programs, the USGA Foundation distributed $1,600 to the USGA for its "Good of the Game" grants to junior golf programs. Additionally, in accordance with a restricted endowment fund to finance turfgrass research programs in the south, the USGA Foundation distributed $2,400 to the USGA for its turfgrass research program.

Form990PartVIISectionA.Title: Board member and Officer through February 2010
Board member and Officer through February 2010
Board member and Officer through February 2010
Assistant Treasurer and USGA Senior Director of Finance
Assistant Secretary and USGA Chief Legal Officer

OtherLiabilities.Description: Due to affiliate, United States Golf Association

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The USGA Foundation has two restricted endowment funds that were created as a result of donations received in the 1980's. The first is used to fund junior golf programs and is the result of a $20,000 donation. The donor specified that only earned income should be used. The USGA Foundation complies with this restriction by using all earned income to fund junior programs in the year the income is earned. The second is used to fund turf research in the south and is the result of a $30,197 donation. The donor specified that only earned income should be used. The USGA Foundation complies with this restriction by using all earned income to fund turf research in the south in the year the income is earned. In both cases, funds are passed to the USGA to fulfill the stated purpose of the restricted endowments.

The Foundation is exempt from federal income taxes under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, except for income derived from unrelated business activities. The Foundation has filed the IRS Federal Form 990, as well as other required forms and returns in various jurisdictions. The Foundation adopted FASB Accounting Standard Codification 740 ("ASC 740"), "Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes". Under ASC 740, an organization must recognize the effect of a tax position when it is more likely than not that the position will be sustained. The Foundation does not believe there are any material uncertain tax positions and, accordingly, has not recognized any liability for uncertain tax positions.

Form990ScheduleJPartIII.Explanation: The USGA Foundation does not have employees. USGA employees are tasked with management duties for the USGA Foundation. (See Federal Form 990 for the USGA)

GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The USGA Foundation serves as a supporting organization for the USGA, as per Section 509(a)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. As such, the USGA Foundation may make contributions to the USGA to help finance its activities. Such donations are fully approved by the Board of Directors of the USGA Foundation and are in accordance with the mission and objectives of the USGA Foundation. (All members of the USGA Executive Committee serve as members of the Board of the USGA Foundation.) Additionally, the USGA Foundation uses assets of the USGA, such as employees and facilities. The USGA Foundation reimburses the USGA for the use of these assets. During 2010, these reimbursements to the USGA resulted in a significant reduction in the USGA Foundation's net assets. This reduction in net assets is normal, and does not represent a liquidation, termination or dissolution of the USGA Foundation.
The estimate for volunteers represents people who serve on the USGA Foundation Board of Directors, as well as the USGA General Counsel.

The museum collection, consisting of graphics, books, and golf memorabilia, is owned by the USGA. The USGA Foundation serves as caretaker. Donations of collectibles are made to the USGA, not to the USGA Foundation. Purchases of collectibles by the USGA Foundation are bought in the name of the USGA and for the benefit of the USGA.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, Line 1a
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The USGA Foundation does not have employees. USGA employees, including the USGA Executive Director, are tasked with management duties for the USGA Foundation. Two USGA employees serve as officers of the USGA Foundation. Those officers are the Assistant Treasurer and the Assistant Secretary.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, Line 6
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The members of the USGA Foundation consist of all persons constituting the USGA Executive Committee, and any additional members that are designated from time to time by the members of the USGA Foundation. The USGA Foundation serves in a supporting organization role, for the benefit of the United States Golf Association and in support of certain specific golf activities. (The USGA Foundation is organized and exists under the Not-For-Profit Corporation Law of the State of New York. The USGA Foundation is a non-stock entity.)

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, Line 7a
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Board of Directors is the governing body of the USGA Foundation. The Board of Directors (members) consist of all persons constituting the USGA Executive Committee, and any additional members that are designated from time to time by the members of the USGA Foundation. The USGA Executive Committee consists of fifteen voting members, including the five officers. Each member of the Executive Committee is elected at the annual meeting of the USGA and holds office until the annual meeting next suceeding his or her election and his or her successor is elected and qualified, or until his or her earlier resignation or removal. Each USGA member club is entitled to be represented by one voting delegate at the annual meeting of the USGA. Duly certified proxies may be voted by voting delegates at the annual meeting of the USGA.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Federal Form 990 is compiled by USGA staff. After the USGA Executive Director and the USGA Senior Director of Finance have thoroughly reviewed the Federal Form 990 and deemed it to be accurate and complete, a copy of the Federal Form 990 is provided to all Board of Directors members for their review. After the Federal Form 990 is reviewed by all Board of Directors members, it is signed by the Assistant Treasurer and submitted to the IRS.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The USGA Foundation requires Board of Directors members to administer their affairs honestly and efficiently, exercising due care, skill and judgement for the benefit of the USGA Foundation. It is the responsibility of Board of Directors members to make a full disclosure of any personal involvement which might result in a conflict of interest on their part. Such disclosures are submitted to the Audit Committee Chairman for review and consideration as per stated procedure. Additionally, once a year, the USGA Foundation requires Board of Directors members to review the USGA Foundation's conflict of interest policy and submit a statement attesting to their understanding and compliance with the policy. Any conflict of interest or appearance of a conflict of interest must be included on the submitted statement. The Audit Committee reviews the statements and makes any necessary decisions to manage and/or eliminate the conflicts.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 16b
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The USGA Foundation has adopted a joint ventures policy to ensure that all arrangements are consistent with the organization's tax exempt status under IRC Section 501 (c)(3). The purpose of this policy is to set forth the guidelines to help ensure that arrangements with for-profit entities will not jeopardize the USGA Foundation's tax-exempt status.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, Line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The USGA Foundation makes the following documents available to the public by providing them to GuideStar to post on their website www.guidestar.org: IRS Letter of Determination, Federal Form 1023, Federal Form 990, audited financial statements, and conflicts of interest policy.
The USGA Foundation does not have employees. USGA employees are tasked with management duties for the USGA Foundation.
The USGA Foundation does not have employees. USGA employees are tasked with management duties for the USGA Foundation.
